body: What you're probably not aware of is that Paul's use of the potter and clay metaphor is based on an earlier Jewish one found in the Dead Sea Scrolls. Some Jews believed the gentiles were vessels prepared for destruction, and Jews were the objects of his glory. Basically, when Jews objected to inviting gentiles, and when Paul says they have rejected God, he is merely using their own logic against them. Basically, "You complain that gentiles are coming in now. But wait, the potter has the right to make some for glory and others for destruction, remember? So who are *you* to object?". Notice how he finishes this section with the comment that it is "so that God may have mercy on them ALL". Plus, Paul's opinion isn't absolute truth anyway.

body:
I think so, unless there is an annihilation that completely destroys all consciousness making it no longer possible to turn around.

On an unrelated note, in my opinion "will not be forgiven" in this case also refers to those in a state of continually rejecting the holy spirit, not those who have in the past and have now repented. Remember Jesus brought it up because some Pharisees had been doing so, and he was trying to convince them to stop, which would be pointless if their fate had already been sealed right then and there.

body:
The view here is Jews vs gentiles, not individuals. I wasn't suggesting universalism, I was arguing against predestination. I don't consider it anything important, but I do think those who believe in it tend to use it as an excuse to elevate themselves. "I'm chosen and you're not, suck it".

I don't believe Romans isn't inspired, though I do recognize that it's still the work of Paul. Although admittedly the Marcionite version did not contain chapters 9-11, and it's possible that could've been the earlier reading, but I'm not sure and don't think I care much either.

body:
> Any sex acts which heighten one's attachment to human sexuality or essentially build up in a direction of sexual perversion shouldn't be done.
> 
> What prevents a Christian from practicing anal sex, or from watching pornography to inspire their sex? The same principle.
> 
> And what prevents Christians from swinging and inviting third people into their marriage bond? This same principle.
> 
> Sex is something to be done for procreative reasons, and for the alleviation of lust; not for building greater levels of lust in the heart.

Except you're not getting this from the bible. This principle comes from Augustine and our puritanical culture. Who says anal sex is bad? I mean it probably is because diseases, but that's not the same reason you think. Pornography is bad because it abuses and exploits people. A third person is adultery. This idea that sex should only be done in the missionary position with as little pleasure as possible is an error. There are actual reasons for not committing adultery and fornication and stuff, it's not because "sex=icky". It's not merely a "necessary evil" for having children. I do think it's somewhat evil, but for different reasons; it causes people to lose their minds, it's responsible for sexual dimorphism, it creates discomfort when you're not having it, and the evil done to gain it is second only to money and power. Sex itself isn't evil, and not having it won't change anything, in fact it makes the effects even worse.

> But, theologically, I want to defend the traditional position of the Orthodox church.

Well that's your problem. You follow a human organization instead of Jesus. His biggest enemies were actually the leaders of the religious institutions established in his name.

> We do not follow the Old Testament laws because this was an old covenant not relevant to us. " In that he saith, A new covenant, he hath made the first old. Now that which decayeth and waxeth old is ready to vanish away." (Hebrews 8:13)

Except for the part about not lying with another man. And not dressing like the other sex, not that one either. But everything else is repealed.

> it is that the old covenant was fulfilled with the crucifixion of Christ, who was the final blood offering & blood sacrifice, and thus these old forms of repentance, and these old laws about purification passed away.

The WHOLE LAW was clearly stated to be two commandments, and this has always been the case (remember, everyone in that day would've understood "law" to mean the OT law). Jesus didn't change anything, he corrected our errors. Does God change his mind? Jesus didn't come to replace the rules with another set of rules, that's like fixing the problem using the problem. He wants to win peoples' hearts. Your only source for the "new" law (which is actually the timeless law) is the two commandments. Everything else is the traditions of men.

parent.body:
>You changed the subject. This was about having oral sex with your spouse, remember?

OK, I crossed the wires, I guess. 

Any sex acts which heighten one's attachment to human sexuality or essentially build up in a direction of sexual perversion shouldn't be done. 

What prevents a Christian from practicing anal sex, or from watching pornography to inspire their sex? The same principle. 

And what prevents Christians from *swinging* and inviting third people into their marriage bond? This same principle. 

Sex is something to be done for procreative reasons, and for the *alleviation* of lust; not for building greater levels of lust in the heart. 

It doesn't explicitly say this in the Bible, but the conclusion follows, just like how the Trinity isn't explicitly stated in the Bible.

>But anyway it's not wrong to love someone while single either. After all if that never happens, there would be no reason to marry in the first place. Remember, problems with fornication have more to do with the risks about abortion, STDs, kids, money, legal battles, etc. And in ancient times, genealogy and blood lineage was very important to people, so any uncertainty over who was really "your" child biologically could be devastating to your entire family and close friends. Having a feeling can't cause any of that. The reason it's different as adultery is because it's unfaithful to your spouse, whether they're aware of it or not. There are actual reasons why things are wrong, it's not some rocket science concept of religious purity and "sex=sin" like you are treating it.

My above response I think generally responds to how I would answer this issue. I think single people ought to be learning how to control their lust. Of course, I am not someone who berates Christians who are *engaged* or in very serious LTRs that end up being sexual. It's really not my business. But, theologically, I want to defend the traditional position of the Orthodox church. 

>Meaning that if something doesn't fit with them, it's a sign that you are either misunderstanding it or it's incorrect. Jesus did not come to change morality or abolish the law except for the part about not lying with another man. God never changes. He said ALL the law is derived from the two commandments. If it's not, you're either misunderstanding it, it's meant for a different setting, or it's corrupt. There was an actual methodology and belief system behind what OT laws Jesus disregarded, it wasn't just him randomly changing his mind about stuff. Remember, for example, that he expected the Pharisees to understand, with the 4th commandment and prescribed stoning to death for so much as getting out of bed on the Sabbath clearly in their scriptures, that it was not wrong for him and the disciples to be harvesting crops on the Sabbath. Notice that Jesus never announced an abolition of the Sabbath, but breaking it did not violate either of the two commandments, and he fully understood this, and therefore it was not wrong.

We do not follow the Old Testament laws because this was an old covenant not relevant to us. 

" In that he saith, A new covenant, he hath made the first old. Now that which decayeth and waxeth old is ready to vanish away." (Hebrews 8:13)

We should not dismiss the totality of the Old Testament as being the work of scribes that were meaningless and trite; it is that the old covenant was fulfilled with the crucifixion of Christ, who was the final blood offering & blood sacrifice, and thus these old forms of repentance, and these old laws about purification passed away.

post.body:
>Hwang is a trustee of the Fuller Theology Seminary, and co-founder of the Grace and Mercy Foundation, whose mission is to serve the poor and oppressed. The foundation had assets approaching $500 million at the end of 2018, according to its latest filing.

>“It’s not all about the money, you know,” he said in a rare interview with a Fuller Institute executive in 2018, in which he spoke about his calling as an investor and his Christian faith. “It’s about the long term, and God certainly has a long-term view.”

More on Fuller Theological seminary: 

>While Fuller has established policies, the seminary is open to difference in opinion among students and faculty.[17] The seminary's current president, Mark Labberton, marched in favor of comprehensive immigration reform and a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants in 2013.[18] Others have expressed support in the Fuller forum for the Black Lives Matter movement as raising awareness for civil rights.[19] In 2015, some faculty at the seminary called on Christians to openly discuss, with respect, issues related to race, gender, sexual orientation, refugees, and immigrants.[20] While the seminary officially recognizes marriage as "between a man and a woman", the seminary did allow an LGBTQ student club to organize on campus; the club, "OneTable", became the first LGBTQ group organized within an evangelical seminary.[21]
post.body_html:
Hwang is a trustee of the Fuller Theology Seminary, and co-founder of the Grace and Mercy Foundation, whose mission is to serve the poor and oppressed. The foundation had assets approaching $500 million at the end of 2018, according to its latest filing.

“It’s not all about the money, you know,” he said in a rare interview with a Fuller Institute executive in 2018, in which he spoke about his calling as an investor and his Christian faith. “It’s about the long term, and God certainly has a long-term view.”

More on Fuller Theological seminary:

While Fuller has established policies, the seminary is open to difference in opinion among students and faculty.[17] The seminary's current president, Mark Labberton, marched in favor of comprehensive immigration reform and a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants in 2013.[18] Others have expressed support in the Fuller forum for the Black Lives Matter movement as raising awareness for civil rights.[19] In 2015, some faculty at the seminary called on Christians to openly discuss, with respect, issues related to race, gender, sexual orientation, refugees, and immigrants.[20] While the seminary officially recognizes marriage as "between a man and a woman", the seminary did allow an LGBTQ student club to organize on campus; the club, "OneTable", became the first LGBTQ group organized within an evangelical seminary.[21]
post.title: One of World’s Greatest Hidden Fortunes Is Wiped Out in Days [God smiting Fuller Theological Seminary?]

body: Unfortunately we only have one fragment from that period. Well there's also [this](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shapira_Scroll) and it *does* line up with the evidence we have, but it could easily be a master forgery and the original fragments no longer exist for testing. Other than that, our oldest is the DSS, which is a few hundred years after the Babylonian captivity when the last major redactions were made.

body:
> There is this idea that a thing can only be bad because of the effect it has on another

Because this is what Jesus taught. In fact it's the only reason he was able to break so many apparently established religious laws. Notice how he did this *before* his crucifixion, this was not dispensationalism. It was the Pharisees and pagans who taught otherwise with their kooky religious rules and traditions.

> To heighten sexuality in our marriage life through aberrant practices and overindulgence will lead to feeding our desires; desires grow the more that they are exercised.

This assumes that any kind of enjoyment or pleasure whatsoever is inherently wrong. This is also part of our puritanical culture, "I like this so it must be something I'm not supposed to do".

> *6 Now as a concession, not a command, I say this.[a] 7 I wish that all were as I myself am. But each has his own gift from God, one of one kind and one of another.
> 
> 8 To the unmarried and the widows I say that it is good for them to remain single, as I am. 9 But if they cannot exercise self-control, they should marry. For it is better to marry than to burn with passion.* (1 Cor. 7)
> 
> The higher ideal is celibacy, and sexuality is something that should be understood in the context of a struggle for self-control.
> 
> So, it is in this tradition that Chrsitians are interested in limiting their sexual indulgence.
> 
> As Christ speaks of celibacy:
> 
> 12 For there are some eunuchs, which were so born from their mother's womb: and there are some eunuchs, which were made eunuchs of men: and there be eunuchs, which have made themselves eunuchs for the kingdom of heaven's sake. He that is able to receive it, let him receive it. (Matthew 19)
> 
> We may not be able to receive celibacy, but certainly, the higher path is to not burn with lust.

You are misunderstanding this. This is about people who choose not to enter into a temporary covenant of the flesh, and focus on God rather than a spouse. It has nothing to do with natural biological desires being wrong. In fact Paul goes out of his way to make sure his readers don't think that, insisting it is *not* wrong in any way to marry, only that it is honorable to choose not to.

> So you think Christians can be gay married and such?

I have no full opinion on this, though I have always been very suspicious about this prohibition and the textual evidence does indeed show it to be spurious. However, what I do know is that it's hypocritical how much churchy people constantly bash "the gays" while being involved in immoral practices themselves. "But we're all sinners though," they say, but these two things are somehow different. I also feel like if they're going judge others based on the OT law, they'd better be following all the other 611 laws too, including the ones about not eating pig meat and not getting out of bed on Saturday, which I can guarantee you 99% of them aren't. I don't recall God ever saying which OT laws still apply and which ones don't, so it's all or nothing, either the whole OT law is still in effect or it's not.

>Except you're not getting this from the bible. This principle comes from Augustine and our puritanical culture. Who says anal sex is bad? I mean it probably is because diseases, but that's not the same reason you think. Pornography is bad because it abuses and exploits people. A third person is adultery. This idea that sex should only be done in the missionary position with as little pleasure as possible is an error. There are actual reasons for not committing adultery and fornication and stuff, it's not because "sex=icky". It's not merely a "necessary evil" for having children. I do think it's somewhat evil, but for different reasons; it causes people to lose their minds, it's responsible for sexual dimorphism, it creates discomfort when you're not having it, and the evil done to gain it is second only to money and power. Sex itself isn't evil, and not having it won't change anything, in fact it makes the effects even worse.

This is enlightenment era thinking talking. 

There is this idea that a thing can only be bad because of the effect it has on another; Christianity has a dynamic and holistic understanding, and we see our own sinful thoughts & the cultivation of greater sinful desires as a negative. 

To heighten sexuality in our marriage life through aberrant practices and overindulgence will lead to feeding our desires; desires grow the more that they are exercised. 

As St. Paul wrote:

*6 Now as a concession, not a command, I say this.[a] 7 I wish that all were as I myself am. But each has his own gift from God, one of one kind and one of another.

The higher ideal is celibacy, and sexuality is something that should be understood in the context of a struggle for self-control.

(Matthew 19)

>Except for the part about not lying with another man. And not dressing like the other sex, not that one either. But everything else is repealed.

So you think Christians can be gay married and such?

>Hwang is a trustee of the Fuller Theology Seminary, and co-founder of the Grace and Mercy Foundation, whose mission is to serve the poor and oppressed. The foundation had assets approaching $500 million at the end of 2018, according to its latest filing.

>“It’s not all about the money, you know,” he said in a rare interview with a Fuller Institute executive in 2018, in which he spoke about his calling as an investor and his Christian faith. “It’s about the long term, and God certainly has a long-term view.”

More on Fuller Theological seminary: 

>While Fuller has established policies, the seminary is open to difference in opinion among students and faculty.[17] The seminary's current president, Mark Labberton, marched in favor of comprehensive immigration reform and a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants in 2013.[18] Others have expressed support in the Fuller forum for the Black Lives Matter movement as raising awareness for civil rights.[19] In 2015, some faculty at the seminary called on Christians to openly discuss, with respect, issues related to race, gender, sexual orientation, refugees, and immigrants.[20] While the seminary officially recognizes marriage as "between a man and a woman", the seminary did allow an LGBTQ student club to organize on campus; the club, "OneTable", became the first LGBTQ group organized within an evangelical seminary.[21]
post.body_html:
Hwang is a trustee of the Fuller Theology Seminary, and co-founder of the Grace and Mercy Foundation, whose mission is to serve the poor and oppressed. The foundation had assets approaching $500 million at the end of 2018, according to its latest filing.

“It’s not all about the money, you know,” he said in a rare interview with a Fuller Institute executive in 2018, in which he spoke about his calling as an investor and his Christian faith. “It’s about the long term, and God certainly has a long-term view.”

More on Fuller Theological seminary:

While Fuller has established policies, the seminary is open to difference in opinion among students and faculty.[17] The seminary's current president, Mark Labberton, marched in favor of comprehensive immigration reform and a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants in 2013.[18] Others have expressed support in the Fuller forum for the Black Lives Matter movement as raising awareness for civil rights.[19] In 2015, some faculty at the seminary called on Christians to openly discuss, with respect, issues related to race, gender, sexual orientation, refugees, and immigrants.[20] While the seminary officially recognizes marriage as "between a man and a woman", the seminary did allow an LGBTQ student club to organize on campus; the club, "OneTable", became the first LGBTQ group organized within an evangelical seminary.[21]
post.title: One of World’s Greatest Hidden Fortunes Is Wiped Out in Days [God smiting Fuller Theological Seminary?]

body:
> So Christ believes that an action is good or bad solely based on how it effects others

Well that's what he said.

> and that one's internal spiritual disposition is irrelevant?

I don't see how that's not the same thing.

> I'm talking about sexuality, which is directly connected to lust.
> 
> Likewise, we try to tell people to curb their appetites so they do not become obsessed with food, and become gluttonous, or to become obsessed with money, and become greedy; to indulge anger, and become irate and aggressive, etc..
> 
> It is sweet & proper to enjoy the company of others, games, song, dance, etc. Of course, moderation in all things, but we are supposed to also enjoy our leisure.

You tell people not to get fat. You don't tell them they can only eat bland foods, and just barely enough to have energy at that.

> Why does Christ and why do St. Paul encourage people to be celibate? Because it is a high, noble path.

You seem to think that this makes the other one wrong. Which it doesn't. Ironically I have even more trouble with the opposite view, people who think not marrying and having 2.5 kids is wrong.

> Why are we told to have sex only in marraige? Because sex performs a spiritual bond between people, and marriage is the only appropriate outlet; it is also a sacred sort of act.

Or maybe it's because of all the bad things that come from doing so? And sex isn't any more "sacred" than any other bodily function. And first you say it's a necessary evil, now you call it sacred. Which is it?

> Yuo are rejecting the teachings of St. Paul on this.

Paul thought people who pass judgement like this have no excuse, because they themselves do bad things. And I agree.

> Then, why believe in Christianity at all? The same people who told us St. Paul's clothes and handkerchiefs healed people are the ones who gave us the Gospels; we only know what we do about Christ through people who revered St. Paul.

I am not aware of any commandment to follow any man, including Paul. And Paul actually criticized people who thought this, to my knowledge, asking in whose name had they been baptized. Distinguishing "apostle" as being anything more than a messenger or evangelizer is a church invention. ΑΠΟΣΤΟΛΟΣ is not a new word invented by Christians, it is merely the Greek term for a messenger. And I have no idea where you're getting the idea that the person who put that insanity in Acts about Paul's clothes healing people wrote all 4 gospels. Luke originally was probably just a Greek version of Matthew (which would've been in Hebrew at the time), which was then adopted by Marcion, and then the church got in a spat with him and adopted edited versions of his texts to "prove" him wrong (Note: I don't support Marcion either, at least not as the the church fathers described him, which is all we know). The first two chapters of Luke appear to have been tacked on by a later editor who was the same person who wrote Acts, who may have also been the main redactor of the rest of the NT canon.

> But you are now saying St. Paul's condemnations of homosexuality are irrelevant and potentially wrong, yes?

The only time Paul can ever be said to have referenced it is in 1 Corinthians 6:9, which is not even clear what it's actually referring to, and I also doubt that Paul wrote this verse at all because he supports justification by faith alone elsewhere, including literally 3 verses later.

> St. Pau also clearly stated why we do not follow Old Testament law.

But for some reason 2 out of those 613 laws are magically different and still apply.

Well that's what he said.

I don't see how that's not the same thing.

Likewise, we try to tell people to curb their appetites so they do not become obsessed with food, and become gluttonous, or to become obsessed with money, and become greedy; to indulge anger, and become irate and aggressive, etc..

It is sweet & proper to enjoy the company of others, games, song, dance, etc. Of course, moderation in all things, but we are supposed to also enjoy our leisure.

You tell people not to get fat. You don't tell them they can only eat bland foods, and just barely enough to have energy at that.

You seem to think that this makes the other one wrong. Which it doesn't. Ironically I have even more trouble with the opposite view, people who think not marrying and having 2.5 kids is wrong.

Or maybe it's because of all the bad things that come from doing so? And sex isn't any more "sacred" than any other bodily function. And first you say it's a necessary evil, now you call it sacred. Which is it?

Yuo are rejecting the teachings of St. Paul on this.

Paul thought people who pass judgement like this have no excuse, because they themselves do bad things. And I agree.

Then, why believe in Christianity at all? The same people who told us St. Paul's clothes and handkerchiefs healed people are the ones who gave us the Gospels; we only know what we do about Christ through people who revered St. Paul.

I am not aware of any commandment to follow any man, including Paul. And Paul actually criticized people who thought this, to my knowledge, asking in whose name had they been baptized. Distinguishing "apostle" as being anything more than a messenger or evangelizer is a church invention. ΑΠΟΣΤΟΛΟΣ is not a new word invented by Christians, it is merely the Greek term for a messenger. And I have no idea where you're getting the idea that the person who put that insanity in Acts about Paul's clothes healing people wrote all 4 gospels. The first two chapters of Luke appear to have been tacked on by a later editor who was the same person who wrote Acts, who may have also been the main redactor of the rest of the NT canon.

But you are now saying St. Paul's condemnations of homosexuality are irrelevant and potentially wrong, yes?

The only time Paul can ever be said to have referenced it is in 1 Corinthians 6:9, which is not even clear what it's actually referring to, and I also doubt that Paul wrote this verse at all because he supports justification by faith alone elsewhere, including literally 3 verses later.

St. Pau also clearly stated why we do not follow Old Testament law.

But for some reason 2 out of those 613 laws are magically different and still apply.

>“It’s not all about the money, you know,” he said in a rare interview with a Fuller Institute executive in 2018, in which he spoke about his calling as an investor and his Christian faith. “It’s about the long term, and God certainly has a long-term view.”

More on Fuller Theological seminary: 

>While Fuller has established policies, the seminary is open to difference in opinion among students and faculty.[17] The seminary's current president, Mark Labberton, marched in favor of comprehensive immigration reform and a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants in 2013.[18] Others have expressed support in the Fuller forum for the Black Lives Matter movement as raising awareness for civil rights.[19] In 2015, some faculty at the seminary called on Christians to openly discuss, with respect, issues related to race, gender, sexual orientation, refugees, and immigrants.[20] While the seminary officially recognizes marriage as "between a man and a woman", the seminary did allow an LGBTQ student club to organize on campus; the club, "OneTable", became the first LGBTQ group organized within an evangelical seminary.[21]
post.body_html:
Hwang is a trustee of the Fuller Theology Seminary, and co-founder of the Grace and Mercy Foundation, whose mission is to serve the poor and oppressed. The foundation had assets approaching $500 million at the end of 2018, according to its latest filing.

“It’s not all about the money, you know,” he said in a rare interview with a Fuller Institute executive in 2018, in which he spoke about his calling as an investor and his Christian faith. “It’s about the long term, and God certainly has a long-term view.”

More on Fuller Theological seminary:

While Fuller has established policies, the seminary is open to difference in opinion among students and faculty.[17] The seminary's current president, Mark Labberton, marched in favor of comprehensive immigration reform and a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants in 2013.[18] Others have expressed support in the Fuller forum for the Black Lives Matter movement as raising awareness for civil rights.[19] In 2015, some faculty at the seminary called on Christians to openly discuss, with respect, issues related to race, gender, sexual orientation, refugees, and immigrants.[20] While the seminary officially recognizes marriage as "between a man and a woman", the seminary did allow an LGBTQ student club to organize on campus; the club, "OneTable", became the first LGBTQ group organized within an evangelical seminary.[21]
post.title: One of World’s Greatest Hidden Fortunes Is Wiped Out in Days [God smiting Fuller Theological Seminary?]

parent.body:
Sorry I misunderstood your point there.  

>those who believe in it tend to use it as an excuse to elevate themselves. "I'm chosen and you're not, suck it".

Then they aren't fully understanding predestination/election since no one but God knows the elect.  (Yes, I believe in personal assurance of salvation, but I can only minister to others in faith that God can use my efforts as he pleases.)

And re: romans 9, I partially agree with your take, in that he is talking about groups of people, but he illustrates the nature of the groups by using examples of individuals in relation to God's choice.  In other words, Paul isn't using his character examples symbolically or "representatively".  I think over all he's clearly talking about the Jews/Gentiles AND the Elect (v24) which is composed not of those who choose salvation on their own (no one can as Paul has explained), but of those that God mercifully chooses (v16).
parent.body_html:
Sorry I misunderstood your point there.

those who believe in it tend to use it as an excuse to elevate themselves. "I'm chosen and you're not, suck it".

Then they aren't fully understanding predestination/election since no one but God knows the elect. (Yes, I believe in personal assurance of salvation, but I can only minister to others in faith that God can use my efforts as he pleases.)

And re: romans 9, I partially agree with your take, in that he is talking about groups of people, but he illustrates the nature of the groups by using examples of individuals in relation to God's choice. In other words, Paul isn't using his character examples symbolically or "representatively". I think over all he's clearly talking about the Jews/Gentiles AND the Elect (v24) which is composed not of those who choose salvation on their own (no one can as Paul has explained), but of those that God mercifully chooses (v16).

parent.body:
Those two Ezekiel passages are talking about repentance though.  So even then though God does not take pleasure in the destruction of his people and wants them to repent, he's not letting them off the hook if they don't.  I don't see how that logically contradicts the idea that God chooses who he will grant life (Eph 2:10).  

John 3:18 grants further clarity into what John's meaning of "the world" is.  Those who don't Believe are condemned already!  John isn't speaking universally here.  While I'm thinking of John, just look ahead to John 6:37: "All that the Father gives me will come to me, and whoever comes to me I will never cast out."  I don't think it's right to assume that God's wringing his hands hoping that people repent - rather, it takes his action.

BTW I've been enjoying this conversation.  Thanks!
parent.body_html:
Those two Ezekiel passages are talking about repentance though. So even then though God does not take pleasure in the destruction of his people and wants them to repent, he's not letting them off the hook if they don't. I don't see how that logically contradicts the idea that God chooses who he will grant life (Eph 2:10).

John 3:18 grants further clarity into what John's meaning of "the world" is. Those who don't Believe are condemned already! John isn't speaking universally here. While I'm thinking of John, just look ahead to John 6:37: "All that the Father gives me will come to me, and whoever comes to me I will never cast out." I don't think it's right to assume that God's wringing his hands hoping that people repent - rather, it takes his action.

BTW I've been enjoying this conversation. Thanks!

parent.body: But this is not meant to be taken so broadly.  I mean, look at Ezekiel 5:13: "Then My anger will be spent and I will satisfy My wrath on them, and I will be appeased; then they will know that I, the Lord, have spoken in My zeal, when I have spent My wrath upon them."  "Pleasure" might not be the first choice of word I would use (because of unhelpful connotation), but God is certainly satisfied in his righteous vengeance (Rom 3:25).  Again, I think it's clear in light of other scripture, that God is speaking in human terms in those passages to offer the olive branch as it were, and I would also submit that Ezekiel's statements should only be understood with regard to his chosen people having fallen away - not as a general attitude toward all.

Mercy was meant for everyone, and some people are too proud to have it, but that's their own fault, and that's why it's the only thing that will stop it (Matthew 12:31). If everything is predestined, why does God not have pleasure in the death of the evil? Why not want anyone to die but then cut half the world off from the option not to? Why evangelize? And indeed, many people use this as their excuse to shut their doors to outsiders, saying, "we're the chosen ones and we don't have time for you inferiors, now shoo!". parent.body: No, I think that's sort of a backwards way to think about it.  I guess I don't have a problem with "double predestination" logically, but I think the correct perspective on God's mercy is wonder that he has mercy on any at all!  There is now no favoritism to Jew or Gentile, I suppose, but we cannot know God's reasoning as to why he chooses some for salvation and not others other than to demonstrate his glory.  Back to Romans - there is no one who is good in God's sight (3:9), so I think of course there is favoritism to those he saves (in his mercy, not because of righteousness he sees in us), right?  How does that make him a hypocrite? "For as in Adam all die, so also in Christ all will be made alive" (1 Cor 15:22).
